heading: 2023-Present
description: A survey of my professional career so far.

sections.description: I enrolled into the Design and Development mentorship program at Perpetual Education. More details about what I learned can be found in my portfolio projects, but I personally gravitated towards anything related to front-end Design.
At my first job as a contractor for Classic City Consulting, we created website landing pages using Gutenberg blocks. Work included anything from social media apps to...
hardware stores! Agency work brings with it variety.
Starting at my second job at Bizcor, I was mainly responsible for content updates and small design tweeks. The occasional bug fix perhaps.
As time went on, clients who were close to me would reach out for feature implementations such as popup design and development, among other things.
My largest projects have been overseeing landing page design and creation. At this point I spend a lot of time talking to clients and our different teams to deliver site updates as needed.

heading: Riche Fashion
description: A research project that implemented design principles found among fashion websites.

sections.caption: The primary inspiration for this project came from Gucci and Prada.
sections.description: The first stage of this project came from researching different high-end fashion companies. I took a few examples of modules or cards to lead my design process for the landing page.

sections.caption: I got these images from Unslpash.com, and I keep a folder of images like this just in case I need them to design a card around.
sections.description: Modules need content! Just like with Croatian Coasts, I keep images like this in storage to pull out when needed, and what I don't have I get from free resources like Unsplash.com

sections.caption: This is an example of a style tile. This serves as the foundation for the design moving forward. Cheap and effective solutions like this allow us to get user feedback quicker, instead of having to spend time creating a fully fleshed mockup to start.
sections.description: I created a style tile like this to organize the module designs, typography choices, and color and spacing ideas. As more modules get made, I can add those designs to the ones seen here.

sections.caption: The landing page is very similar to the sites that inspired it. Compared to the original modules seen from Gucci and Prada, this gives a monocolored spin on the large blocky font and images to accentuate the models and clothing.
Once the items are compared, they are pushed into the new filtered array.
sections.description: A quick example of item filtering. I check the value of what collection the item is included in and compare it to the collection number. This project was a great exercise in designing a high-end fashion site. Some of the hardest problems were figuring out the filtering and choosing what content would be best. I may add more items or functionality in the future!

heading: Responsive Garden
description: A series of responsive JSON backed modules to practice mobile-first design using pure PHP.

sections.caption: An example of three modules that are unique to the first page. This is a living project where new modules can be added as time goes on. I always operate on a mobile-first basis.
sections.description: This collection of responsive modules serves as a place where I can add more as time goes on. Each page has two different versions of the same module - that becomes populated with data that is unique to the pages with styles that are based on the page the module is on.

sections.caption: This article grid uses the same HTML as page 1's article grid, but has different styles based on the value of the page in JSON.
An example of one such module, with variables linked to JSON at the top. That JSON then populates the module's HTML.
An example of JSON for two modules that populates templates like the one seen above.
sections.description: This project taught me a lot about scope and planning. I learned that I could tie CSS rules to the JSON as well, and that allows me to set unique CSS depending on the page. I used grid extensively on this project and that proved to be extremely useful! Splitting the page into separate modules allowed me to use JSON to give them distinct text and CSS.
